Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding, Mitigating, and Controlling Frost Formation Through the Use of Biphilic and Hybrid Surfaces under Static and Dynamic Conditions

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Frost formation is a common occurrence that penalizes energy consumption; it builds up in freezers, covers car windows, and prevents heat pump air-conditioners from properly functioning. It also has harmful effects in applications such as airplane safety and reliability. This research will investigate new surfaces that combine water-attracting and water-repelling regions to prevent and control frost formation. During the frost formation process, water coexists as vapor, liquid, and solid phases. By using surfaces with resilient and optimally positioned interlaced patterns of water-attracting and water-repelling regions, the transport of the water is controlled before it freezes. Preliminary results show that controlling the transport of water in the liquid and vapor phases can significantly increase the amount of time it takes for freezing to occur and even prevent frost altogether for certain temperature ranges. Even after water initially freezes on a surface, frost continues to grow three-dimensionally leading to thick build-up of frost. The growth of the frost layer is predominately dependent of water vapor transport. A surface that can selectively attract and repel water vapor has the potential to change the frost growth pattern and to limit the thickness of the frost layer. The objective of this work is to investigate various patterns of water-attracting and water-repelling regions on surfaces and on fin structures and to discover the widest temperature range possible were frost can be completely prevented as well as determine how frost formation can be optimally controlled for significantly less energy consumption in applications in which the conditions are beyond frost prevention.

This project will fundamentally investigate new mixed hydrophilic and hydrophobic surfaces that generate and coalesce supercooled water droplets, that is, water droplets that remain in the liquid phase at and below freezing temperature. The interlaced coatings pragmatically relocate these droplets on the heat transfer surfaces. These new concepts mitigate frost growth, control frost loading, and maximizes energy conversion efficiencies. The investigation will be approached collaboratively: Kansas State University will develop the surfaces and study the droplets in quiescence conditions while Auburn University will characterize the resilience of the anti-frost properties of the new surfaces under convective dynamic conditions on fin structures. The objective of this research is to advance the understanding of how these coatings affect the frost nucleation and structure during growth. A major innovation from the proposed research will be a robust surface that provides significantly reduced frost layer, which will greatly minimize thermal resistance and air flow blockage. This will immediately augment the energy conversion efficiencies of refrigeration systems and air-cooled condensers. The experimental results from this work will be also used to strengthen the models developed by the research team for designing frost mitigating surfaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Frost formation is a common occurrence that has harmful effects in several engineering applications such as aircraft safety and reliability, refrigeration and building energy conversion systems, air-cooled condensers, wind turbines, and power transmission. For several of these applications, frost formation cannot be prevented and it significantly penalizes the energy conversion performance (see for example Figure 1).

This research fundamentally investigated new surface coatings that combined water-attracting (hydrophilic) and water-repelling (hydrophobic) regions to control the onset of frost formation. During the frost nucleation processes, water coexists as vapor, liquid, and solid phases. The new coatings investigated in this research restrained the droplets phase such that droplets remained in the liquid state well below freezing temperature. By using coating with optimally positioned interlaced patterns of water-attracting and water-repelling regions, the freezing of the water droplets was delayed and the transport and packing of the water droplets on the heat transfer surfaces were controlled before freezing. These new concepts mitigated frost growth, controlled frost loading, and can maximize energy conversion efficiencies.

An new experimental methodology was developed to measure freezing time, droplets diameter, and droplets and iced beads temperature at the onset of frost nucleation, as shown in Figure 2. Results showed that the initial conditions of the surfaces and contamination level after multiple frost and defrost cycles played key roles in characterizing the frost nucleation (see Figure 3). Overall, hydrophobic and super-hydrophobic surfaces increased the amount of time it took for freezing to occur and even prevented frost altogether for certain temperatures and humidity. In most applications, such as airplane safety, complete prevention of frost is the desired outcome. In other applications, such as residential and commercial heat pumps and industrial refrigeration, the temperatures might be too low to prevent frost growth. Fortunately, in these applications, frost only becomes a significant issue when very thick layers build up and they obstruct the airflow through fins of heat exchangers. In these applications, the experimental results indicated that hydrophilic and super-hydrophilic surfaces measured shorted periods at which water droplets turned into ice beads and yet only thin layers of frost were produced. The periods before blocking the air flows were longer than the ones without using any surface coating. The water was practically pulled toward the super-hydrophilic coated heat transfer surface and a thin dense frost layer was generated.

A bi-philic surface that can selectively attract and repel water vapor has the potential to extent the freezing time, change the frost growth pattern, and limit the thickness of the frost layer. Some experimentally measured freezing times are shown in Figure 4. From this point of view, this research advanced the understanding of how these coatings affected the frost nucleation and structure during growth. A new model of droplet growth and freezing on heat exchanger fins was developed for fin structures under forced convective flows. The model focused on environmental conditions typical of heat pump systems, for which fins temperature can be only 5 to 10?C below the freezing temperature. This is the range in which frost nucleation is most unpredictable but also in which surface wettability characteristics can appreciably control frost loading on finned structures. Classical nucleation and dropwise condensation theories were combined with statistical methods and new empirical correlations to fully predict droplet size and coverage during progressive water vapor condensation up to frost nucleation and freezing. The newly developed model was experimentally validated with data of droplet growth and freezing on flat surfaces of various wettabilities and for surface temperatures of few degrees below the triple point of water (see Figure 5). Model results indicated that variations of humidity, air velocity, and surface temperature affected significantly droplet growth and freezing. This was due to the resulting variations in the heat and mass transfer driving potentials. Static contact angle primarily affected droplet growth by directly altering the geometry and coalescence behavior of the liquid droplets formed on the cold surfaces.

Finally, since frost formation is a common experience it provided excellent projects for incorporating into educational and outreach activities and engage and excite young people about the potential of engineering.
